body: so happy to have this change in.. thanks @anuraaga

response back to users is less than awesome on this first request while health check booting up

```
curl -X POST -s localhost:9411/api/v2/spans -H'Content-Type: application/json' -d @netflix.json
com.linecorp.armeria.client.endpoint.EndpointGroupException: com.linecorp.armeria.client.endpoint.OrElseEndpointGroup@5865d659 is empty
```
ok this is ready cc @anuraaga @kojilin @trustin
thanks as this is very repeatable I can try it locally!
It repros locally too? I'm quite impressed by how slow DNS is in practice...
the good looks are mostly @tacigar heh
neat. will test it locally in a bit
things are good!
thanks for the help here.. will look at other details to see if we can release in the next few days or not!

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws/pull/135 with fingers crossed will now work
meh not completely unwound yet.. false alarm

Redirect is up: ``` $ curl -D- https://zipkin.apache.org/quickstart.html HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2019 08:32:06 GMT Server: Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu) Location: https://zipkin.io/quickstart.html Content-Length: 241 Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1 301 Moved Permanently

Moved Permanently

The document has moved here.

```

cc @openzipkin/core indicate your opinion on this.. we do want to get out of a thrash on the topic. on one hand, yes it isn't statistically significant. on the other hand, it is a different way to navigate to a trace ID.

I think the scatter graph's popularity in Pinpoint may largely be a case of user familiarity with it, 100% traces, and no limits on search results. None of this is the typical case for Zipkin users.
Due to these things, I still find it misleading for most typical users. I do think it can be helpful in the way described in the issue description, but that's for a user that understands all of these differences.

If we agree that the problem described in the issue description (too many steps to get to the traces one wants to find, I think) is a problem worth solving, I'd like to explore potential solutions not limited to a scatter graph, which is just one solution with a lot of other effects to consider.

Ideally, I'd like to hear from some Zipkin end users on scenarios in which they use Zipkin, run into the described issue, and how we can best optimize that. The context is important. For example, in the scenario given in the issue description:

> For example, when user's service get a latency problem, if there is not the scatter graph, I think the user operates like the following in UI.

How does the user know that a service has a latency problem? I would say probably from an alert based on metrics. That makes me think the previously discussed integration with Grafana is a better place to focus than adding a scatter graph to Zipkin. Metrics which are aggregated from all requests can already be used to produce a heatmap/histogram much more efficiently than Zipkin can right now (if at all). If we can make the step from there (a metrics view) to viewing relevant traces, perhaps the problem is solved without a scatter graph?

Of course, maybe my assumptions in the scenario are wrong, and certainly there are other solutions, but that's why I would like to get feedback from an end user on the full use case scenario and not limit ourselves to thinking about only solving something with a scatter graph.

one thing this does is similar to the new twitter UI. it takes a large amount of space away from viewing results, pushing the eyes down and center.

I'm wondering if we can revisit this after we add a topological view also simultaneously considered.

Considering that is also a view based on aspects including latency I'm wondering if it is really necessary to also add more here. The other problem with adding this is it temps a lot of small adjustments and feature requests like zoom in the scatter etc.

I've disabled the client-side health checking in an attempt to at least get to something functional as we can't keep holding the whole repo hostage and until things work, that's what's happening.

against a local node, this works except there's one of these things.. aws doesn't work and I can't quite tell why not as logging isn't working.

I think the above error is interfering with self-tracing as I don't get any client spans, only the spans above it.

also I think there's something about the raw body decorator which is incompatible with the client usage here.. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws/pull/135/files#diff-c2299f75862484516908a6b48313a9e1R59

this is interfering with my ability to figure out what if anything is wrong with the signature code when sent against the elasticsearch domains endpoint

even when removing the health check stuff there's still a problem I've not seen in any other http client where we can have no results due to dns lag. it seems possibly a good idea to still block on dns to resolve rather than error DnsAddressEndpointGroup

com.linecorp.armeria.client.endpoint.EndpointGroupException: com.linecorp.armeria.client.endpoint.dns.DnsAddressEndpointGroup@7ede1e6a is empty

ok there's no more problem with DNS crashing requests.

The below is still a problem with the reference count thing regardless of local use or not. I will try to hunt which of the changes tripped this

ok this is now operable. I really don't want any more variables like client health check until aws works again as this effort is bleeding time. Let's do that stuff in a separate PR when the time is right.

I'll take a look at the signature tomorrow too, hoping just step-debugging the two versions of the signature will be enlightening enough without actually starting something in the cloud.

Without the health check, if an endpoint goes down we'll round-robin through them all and fail 1/N of requests as it won't fall back in case of connection failure - I believe the pseudo address set thing allowed it to fallback in case of connection failure. I don't know if this is too much of a regression or affects when the time is right.

I've added a backport test of signed output comparing against boto. (`aws --debug es describe-elasticsearch-domain  --domain-name zipkin`)

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws/pull/135

Let's move the conversation there and we can get back to more cleanups and tidies once things are working. thanks for the support

not sure we opened an issue because the issue might end up being a new repo
I guess

Thank you for your feed back @adriancole.

> one thing this does is similar to the new twitter UI. it takes a large amount of space away from viewing results, pushing the eyes down and center.

Yes I totally agree on this.
But I think we can set the toggle button as follows.

![scatter-toggle](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/62180209-23dc2700-b38a-11e9-9e7c-8d3e82a4b099.gif)

The reason I want a scatter chart is that if we look at the scatter chart we can see at a glance which traces are causing problems with latency.

Ofcourse, I think we can revisit this after adding a topological view.
What is the corresponding command for â€œSTORAGE_TYPE=mysql MYSQL_USER=root java -jar zipkin.jarâ€ under cmd? I succeeded in Ubuntu, but the cmd in Windows has never been successful.

the toggle if collapsed by default could be a way out.


speaking from experience on another topic you should bear in mind. The more
features we add, the more reliance we are on more hands to do anything. For
example, consider if you switched careers because of your love of ramen.
Whoever maintains the code next needs to maintain every feature we have
added. This means a hard choice on what features to add, are they worth it?
are they worth the next person's time? this is why we try the "rule of
three" to make sure that others buy-in not just to the idea of if the
feature seems nice, but they personally would help with maintainance or
questions about it. This paragraph is not saying scatterplot would break
the camel's back.. just I'm in a position personally right now of
reflection and I think we add things faster than we can support them
sometimes. it is worth considering where we spend effort and how much value
we get from unit of maintenance.

I think we should have flags to disable health check and configure the check interval (default is 3s). We'll export the health check status to micrometer. 

Okhttp is cool in falling back to the next IP in a DNS response if connect fails but Armeria currently doesn't. We're currently working on a big redesign to combine endpoint selection and connection acquisition at which point I think that becomes somewhat simple to implement but it will take some time.

So there isn't really any option not to issue http requests from an armeria endpoint group for now, and the above flags should keep it manageable I think.
Closing this as Zipkin has withdrawn from the Apache Incubator.

hmm weird it worked before

> why do we back off when the busy queue is full, but not when the health check is red

The point of throttling is to slow your throughput in order to make sure we don't overwhelm storage.  If storage is dead, it doesn't matter how slow we go, it won't be able to store anything.  We also don't ever slow to 0 so messages will continue to drop while it is down.  I suppose you could argue that storage "could revive", in which case, the buffered items should be persisted.  But this is just my 2 cents. If it is decided that buffering while storage is dead is acceptable then I won't argue against it :)
I agree with you :) But have crossed the burnout line so prefer to make changes without thinking too much. If there's a better approach I'm happy to help review it.

your comments make total sense, craig. I think you (luckily) missed some
context that there are sometimes where blips of unavailability occur and it
would seem the same for the reasons you earlier mentioned. If things are
super down, the bounding of the queue should sort it out (drop all).

Also, the context missed .. or maybe not missed heh.. is what Rag said, we
are super dead right now. Maybe this leads to nervousness to not drop on
blips found a day or two ago, or reduce the effort of hunting errors which
was super real this last week.  This context prioritizes these perhaps
artificially more than others.

Even more foreground is that the server hasn't released in ages (in zipkin
years), and also no one finished the exception handling from when this
feature started (ex no one looked at cassandra). So there's a pressure to
complete things also, and not letting best be enemy of good, especially
when probably no one will give feedback on the cassandra stuff.

Anyway sorry for curtness, but I agree with Rag on let's make room for
getting server releasable. Strong feeling will need BYO(change) because we
are dead tired.

Results make sense now. The whole point of the pending change to use rate-limited sampler was to be able to safely trace post requests. Now, you can see that the local (self-tracing) metrics match expectations. In this case a 100s burst of traces and we end up with 204 spans (102 traces).

disregard, this isn't repeatable enough. I just turn on debug logging and have had 3 clean runs with no drops. I do see some issues in tracing of throttled stuff, though, but I'll carry that on somewhere else

PS the reason I want this is to be able to run full self-tracing under load. This will help identify what exactly caused errors that drop spans due to rejection. This is really hard to figure out without tracing.

here's a trace where you can see blocking at play: zoomed to the place where you can see the issue Note @shakuzen @tacigar this is a good example of a trace that has very few spans, but still needs zoom. I take back <10 being good for removing mini-map, if it also means removing zoom. That said, if I could re-root the throttled span, it would be fine in this case!
very interesting that the self-tracing of the "accept-spans" command takes so long to complete... doesn't quite make sense to me at the moment, but it is a lot later than the storage call..
the long time for "accept-spans" to return is a different topic I think, possibly it is because of reading the body. depends on how the client trace is instrumented. Ex this is without throttling..
looks like here blocking could be an intended side-effect of the limiter listener. adding a commit about it, and also adding metrics because it is currently invisible when any capacity errors occur.

putting this down a bit, but feeling positive!
### Current state * Use SVG for trace graph * Fix page header * Add trace tree lines

### Current State * Add span detail on the right side of the page. In #2525 , I said that I wanted to set the span details on the right side of the page. And I got some feedback about it. As a result of thinking, by providing a button to collapse the span details, now I think that the point of concerns may be resolved.

more later but a couple thoughts.. thanks for the feedback.


 The problem in the async reporter stating traces is presence of the global
sampler. unless the global sampler is set to always deny, a call starting
from a reporter thread will sample subject to the rate limit. this is
because it is not a client span rather a local one. we can change this by
moving the rate limiter to inside the http sampler and set the global one
to deny. this will rid need of that thread check stuff in our case.

regardless some of this defensiveness is to also rid that warning message
from armeria's currenttracecontext instance. There will be request scoped
stuff happening alongside not request scoped. any case of the latter.. even
unsampled will trigger that darned message. haven't thought about how to
get rid of it in a better way that literally removing instrumentation.

disabled the logger vs keep digging a hole and piling up beans around the log reporter thread. https://github.com/line/armeria/issues/1964 should help us discuss what to do. I don't think zipkin server will be the only app using both request-originated traffic and also not. We need to work out a good solution, but for now disabling the log vs adding spaghetti.

hmm I have never taken on faith that a one thread writing a value (ex
Armeria's blocking thread pool) will be available for reading by a
different thread (ex this different thread pool) without synchronization
volatile or otherwise.

@trustin @anuraaga would you be comfortable with this? I can learn just
this is new to me.. I would be tempted to say which JVMs provide flush
guarantees as currently we work with jre 1.8 plus and this is the first
time I am hearing about this shortcut...

> <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2735#discussion_r310876255>:
>
> >    }
>
>    @Override public String toString() {
>      return "Throttled(" + delegate + ")";
>    }
>
> -  static String setCurrentThreadName(String name) {
> -    Thread thread = Thread.currentThread();
> -    String originalName = thread.getName();
> -    thread.setName(name);
> -    return originalName;
> +  static final class AwaitableCallback implements Callback<Void> {
> +    final CountDownLatch countDown = new CountDownLatch(1);
> +    final AtomicReference<Throwable> throwable = new AtomicReference<>();
>
> You can consider volatile though I personally wouldn't. I believe the
> semantics around Threads and variable assignment are safe enough that the
> assignment of that value should resolve before attempting to read it.
> Simply because the Thread doing the read is waiting for the entire writing
> Thread to finish before progressing. So the write implictly has to succeed
> before the read will even be attempted. Assuming of course that this is
> only used in doExecute().
>
> Normally, volatile variables are used where there is a high likelihood of
> near-concurrent read/write. Which again, I don't think is the case here.
>

good point on happens before, and sorry to hijack this as a programming
lesson for me but in the name of me spreading to others.. does happens
before imply the same as flush? closest trick I have seen to a cheap
rendezvous was a single length array used with the same.. just never yet
heard that timing implies flush to other threads yet

Yup - happens-before is JDK jargon for implying memory is flushed so subsequent reads definitely see it.

More details are in this well written summary, probably a good read - https://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/package-summary.html#MemoryVisibility

thanks for bearing with me guys. I now know more than before and will
happily clean out other overly defensive things
